questions.question_text: Which two configuration steps must a VMware Cloud Foundation administrator apply to achieve north/south connectivity while setting up an edge VM node for a workload domain from the SDDC Manager user interface? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Lots of confusion on the differences between uplinks, NSX uplinks are configured as part of edge cluster deployment: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-admin/GUID-D17D0274-7764-43BD-8252-D9333CA7415A.html

Selected Answer: BE
BE is correct . NSX vDS uplinks are done as part of host prep
BE is correct . NSX vDS uplinks are done as part of host prep ..

I do think options C and E are the correct ones.

Since the question says "while setting up an edge VM ... from the SDDC Manager user interface" I think that the question refers to the process of adding the edge cluster itself, note that this process deploys the edge cluster as well as a T0 GW along with its uplinks and also the BGP neighbor-ship.

Note that a wizard 'ADD EDGE CLUSTER' launches from the SDDC Manager and asks for all the info [ Edge node names, IPs, VLANs, T0 uplinks, AS for BGP, Edge cluster name, MTU, T0 name, T1 name, Edge cluster type, root/admin/audit credentials, edge nodes’ form factor, T0 routing type (only able to choose static or EBGP; no OSPF available), Edge Nodes’ FQDN, Edge Nodes’ TEP IPs and VLAN tags, T0 uplink VLANs and uplink interface CIDR, BGP peer, ASN, BGP peer password ] regarding the deployment. 

- YoMeroElCarpintero

comments.content:
By the way : C. NSX VDS Uplinks: This is required to connect the edge VM node to the NSX-T Data Center logical network. The administrator needs to configure the NSX Virtual Distributed Switch (VDS) uplinks to provide connectivity to the logical network.
 It should be PREPARED before Edge deployment. it's a pre-requisite (a check box that you have to check before deploying any Edge cluster)
your right BGP is right answer, as vSphere VDS Uplinks not part of setting up an edge VM node
NSX-VDS Uplink is right. But you need BGP information as per documentation : https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.5/vcf-admin/GUID-D17D0274-7764-43BD-8252-D9333CA7415A.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
The two configuration steps that a VMware Cloud Foundation administrator must apply to achieve north/south connectivity while setting up an edge VM node for a workload domain from the SDDC Manager user interface are:

B. vSphere VDS Uplinks: This is required to connect the edge VM node to the upstream physical network. The administrator needs to configure the vSphere Virtual Distributed Switch (VDS) uplinks to provide connectivity to the external network.

C. NSX VDS Uplinks: This is required to connect the edge VM node to the NSX-T Data Center logical network. The administrator needs to configure the NSX Virtual Distributed Switch (VDS) uplinks to provide connectivity to the logical network.

Therefore, options B and C are the correct choices. Options A, D, and E are not directly related to achieving north/south connectivity for an edge VM node in a workload domain.

questions.question_text:
An architect needs to create a VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) VI Workload Domain design with the following requirements:

• Design blueprint needs to be repeatable for additional regions
• Multiple availability zones
• Seven nodes per availability zone to host the workloads
• vSAN storage will be used

What is the maximum accepted latency supported by vMotion between the two availability zones?

choices.A: Manually change the password in SDDC Manager using the “Update” button.
choices.C: Schedule the password rotation in SDDC Manager in the next five minutes using the “Schedule Rotation” button.
choices.B: Remediate the password in SDDC Manager using the “Remediate” button.
choices.D: Rotate the password in SDDC Manager using the “Rotate Now” button.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
You should remediate the password. That option is used to sync password that were changed direclly on component product managed by SDDC manager.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-admin/GUID-92E16E2F-9053-4BBA-9BF9-7B5065C680CF.html

questions.question_text:
An administrator is tasked with resetting a root password which has expired for one of the Workspace One Access (WSA) cluster nodes. The administrator has already reset the password directly on the WSA cluster node(s).

Which additional step must the administrator take to update the password in the SDDC Manager database?

choices.D:
1. vSAN witness host
2. NSX-T
3. vCenter Server
4. ESXi hosts
choices.C:
1. vSAN witness host
2. NSX-T
3. ESXi hosts
4. vCenter Server
choices.A:
1. NSX-T
2. vCenter Server
3. ESXi hosts
4. vSAN Witness host
choices.B:
1. vCenter Server
2. NSX-T
3. ESXi hosts
4. vSAN Witness host

questions.question_text: What is the correct upgrade order for VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) components for a VI workload domain with a stretched vSAN cluster?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D:
When upgrading a VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) VI workload domain with a stretched vSAN cluster, the correct upgrade order is to first upgrade the vSAN witness host, followed by NSX-T Data Center, then vCenter Server, and finally, the ESXi hosts on the cluster; essentially, prioritize the witness host before any other cluster nodes in a stretched vSAN environment. 
 
Key points to remember:
Upgrade the witness host first:
Always upgrade the vSAN witness host before upgrading any other hosts in a stretched vSAN cluster

comments.content: the VSAN Witness hosts must be Always the last one

discussion.content: There are no correct answers. The order is NSX-T >> vCenter Server >> vSAN Witness Host >> ESXi. If you had to pick one it would be answer A since it is the closest. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.5/vcf-lifecycle/GUID-3B41CF79-C721-4AFC-A263-0672143DF41E.html

Selected Answer: B
"In the vSphere Client, browse to the vCenter cluster where Workload Management is enabled.
Select Configure.
Select Supervisor Cluster.
Select Image Registry.
Click Enable Harbor.
Select the Storage Policy for placement of container images.
Click OK to complete the process"

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-AE24CF79-3C74-4CCD-B7C7-757AD082D86A.html

-YoMeroElFrutero
